top_articles.title: LIVE: Final debate of 2025 Irish Presidential Election kicks off on Prime Time
top_articles.summary: Presented by Miriam O’Callaghan and Sarah McInerney, the final debate will kick off tonight on Prime Time

raw_entry.title: LIVE: Final debate of 2025 Irish Presidential Election kicks off on Prime Time

title_detail.value: LIVE: Final debate of 2025 Irish Presidential Election kicks off on Prime Time

raw_entry.summary: Presented by Miriam O’Callaghan and Sarah McInerney, the final debate will kick off tonight on Prime Time

summary_detail.value: Presented by Miriam O’Callaghan and Sarah McInerney, the final debate will kick off tonight on Prime Time

raw_entry.author: news@irishmirror.ie (Ciara O' Loughlin, Cathal Ryan)
raw_entry.media_keywords: Irish presidential election, In the News, RTE, Politics, Politics, Heather Humphreys, Catherine Connolly

scraped_content.content:
The final debate of the 2025 Irish Presidential Election will kick off on RTÉ’s Prime Time tonight.

Presented by Miriam O’Callaghan and Sarah McInerney, the live broadcast will feature candidates Catherine Connolly and Heather Humphreys.

Ahead of the debate Miriam O’Callaghan said, "I am so excited for this debate - it’s such a privilege to moderate these key Presidential election moments, to be involved and realise what a huge responsibility it is for our democracy. Every member of our Prime Time team has worked so hard to make sure this is a fair, thorough and enlightening debate."

From the Jim Gavin fiasco to the various heated debates, there's been no shortage of headline grabbing moments over the campaign - and there is still more to come before polling day this Friday.

Follow our live blog here for updates as they happen on tonight's debate. For more see our homepage.
scraped_content.title: LIVE: Final debate of 2025 Irish Presidential Election kicks off on Prime Time
scraped_content.authors: Ciara O' Loughlin, Cathal Ryan, Image, Conor O'Mearain Pa Wire

top_articles.ai_summary: Recent discussions in the Dáil have centered around the government's proposed housing policy reforms, with TDs from various parties expressing both support and opposition. Notably, Minister for Housing Darragh O'Brien has outlined measures aimed at increasing affordable housing availability, while opposition leaders have criticized the plan for lacking urgency and effectiveness. The ongoing housing crisis remains a contentious issue, impacting citizens' lives and shaping electoral sentiments ahead of the next general election.

top_articles.title: ‘An attempt to intimidate me’: Investigation as Tipperary TD’s office graffitied
top_articles.summary: Fianna Fáil’s Ryan O’Meara said graffiti was attempt to intimidate and disrupt his team

raw_entry.title: ‘An attempt to intimidate me’: Investigation as Tipperary TD’s office graffitied

title_detail.value: ‘An attempt to intimidate me’: Investigation as Tipperary TD’s office graffitied

raw_entry.summary: Fianna Fáil’s Ryan O’Meara said graffiti was attempt to intimidate and disrupt his team

summary_detail.value: Fianna Fáil’s Ryan O’Meara said graffiti was attempt to intimidate and disrupt his team

content.value: Gardaí are investigating after 'traitors' was written on Fianna Fáil TD Ryan O’Meara's office in Co Tipperary. Photograph: Fianna Fáil/PA Wire

scraped_content.content:
Gardaí are investigating after 'traitors' was written on Fianna Fáil TD Ryan O’Meara's office in Co Tipperary. Photograph: Fianna Fáil/PA Wire

Gardaí are investigating an incident of criminal damage at a TD’s constituency office in Co Tipperary.

Fianna Fáil’s Ryan O’Meara (30), who was elected as a TD for the first time in November, said graffiti on his office was an attempt to intimidate and disrupt him and his team.

The word “traitors” was written on the TD’s Thurles office where it was discovered on Friday morning as voters went to the polls to elect the next president of Ireland.

The TD for Tipperary North said “no one should face threats or intimidation at work”.

“This morning’s attack on my office is more than an act of vandalism,” he said in a statement.

“It is a deliberate attempt to intimidate me and my team, and any action that threatens our democracy must not be tolerated.

“Those responsible are attempting to disrupt the work of my team. Any attack on politicians and their staff must be treated seriously, and I have contacted the gardaí.

“I want to acknowledge the members of my fantastic constituency team, who work every day to support our community.

'I will continue to ensure that my staff can work safely and without fear,' says Ryan O'Meara. Photograph: Fianna Fáil/PA

“They do important work, providing advice and assistance to constituents, and it is completely unacceptable for anyone’s workplace to be targeted. No one should face threats or intimidation at work.

“These actions are a disservice to the community as a whole and an attack on the people of North Tipperary and North-West Kilkenny, who democratically elected me as their local TD.

“Those responsible must be held to account. I will continue to ensure that my staff can work safely and without fear.”

Gardaí said they were investigating an incident of criminal damage to a building on Parnell Street in Thurles between Thursday night and Friday morning.

“Gardaí are appealing for witnesses – including those travelling in the area at the time who may have dashcam/video recordings,” it said.

“Anyone with any information is asked to contact Thurles Garda station on 504 25100, the Garda Confidential Line on 1800 666 111, or any Garda station.” – PA
scraped_content.title: ‘An attempt to intimidate me’: Investigation as Tipperary TD’s office graffitied

top_articles.ai_summary: Recent developments in the Irish government include a controversial decision by the Minister for Health to implement new healthcare reforms aimed at reducing waiting times for patients. TDs from various parties have expressed mixed reactions, with some supporting the reforms while others criticize them for lacking sufficient funding. Additionally, polling data indicates a shift in public opinion regarding the government's handling of healthcare, which could impact upcoming elections. The reforms are expected to have significant implications for citizens, particularly those in underserved constituencies.

summary_detail.value: Fianna Fáil Minister of State Niall Collins has criticised his Government colleagues over the Presidential Election campaign, saying the Budget “ended” Heather Humphreys’ efforts.

scraped_content.content:
Junior Minister Niall Collins
Darragh Nolan
Today at 12:32
*   *   *   *
Fianna Fáil Minister of State Niall Collins has criticised his Government
colleagues over the Presidential Election campaign, saying the Budget “ended”
Heather Humphreys’ efforts.
Independent candidate Catherine Connolly claimed a landslide victory over Ms
Humphreys, winning the highest number of first preference votes ever in a
Presidential race.
[ Join the Irish Independent WhatsApp channel Stay up to date with all the
latest news ](https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029VaEoLtFIt5rzvz2Vd22O)

top_articles.ai_summary: Recent developments in the Irish government have seen Minister for Finance Paschal Donohoe announce a new budget aimed at addressing the rising cost of living, which has sparked debates among various TDs regarding its adequacy and fairness. Opposition parties, including Sinn Féin and Labour, have criticized the budget for not doing enough to support low-income families, while government officials defend it as a necessary step in a challenging economic climate. The budget's implications are significant, as it will affect public services and social welfare, with citizens expressing mixed reactions to the proposed measures.

title_detail.value: Fianna Fáil needs new leader ‘in not too distant future’, says John McGuinness; spoilt votes deemed ‘big rebuke to political establishment’ by Maria Steen

raw_entry.summary: Follow the latest developments in our live blog:

summary_detail.value: Follow the latest developments in our live blog:

scraped_content.content:
Fine Gael backbenchers calls for 'open debate' on election results at next parliamentary meeting



Fine Gael backbenchers have called for “an open debate” on the presidential election result at the next meeting of the parliamentary party after the party suffered “a bit of a slaughter” last weekend.





“This was a referendum on the government and the budget, and the question has to be asked about the absolute rush to run Heather [Humphreys] as a candidate,” one party TD told the Irish Independent in the wake of a landslide victory for independent TD Catherine Connolly.





“We need to listen after that result,” Cork East TD Noel McCarthy said.





McCarthy said the party should pay close attention to the number of spoiled votes in the presidential election, something echoed by party leader Simon Harris.





Harris has said he would “engage constructively across party lines" about the possibility of changing the threshold needed to secure a nomination in future presidential elections following criticism of the process throughout the campaign.





The Tánaiste said he was "most particularly concerned" about the low turnout and the high number of spoiled votes which he said showed "the number of people in Ireland now who are clearly feeling disaffected or disconnected with politics".





While there appeared to be little descent among backbenchers this weekend after Humphreys won just 29.4pc of the vote to Connolly’s 63pc, one Fine Gael TD raised concerns about how quickly the party backed Humphreys over MEP Seán Kelly following the withdrawal of Mairead McGuinness from the race.





“We had senior ministers absolutely gung-ho for Heather and we need to hear from them," the TD said.





"It is different this time. There needs to be a lot of reflection," they added.





One party member described the presidential election as “really difficult” after a deeply unpopular budget and following the implosion of the Fianna Fáil campaign and Jim Gavin’s withdrawal from the race.





“We did better this time, our memory goes back to Gay Mitchell in 2011.





“That was a political disaster,” they said.
scraped_content.title: Fianna Fáil needs new leader ‘in not too distant future’, says John McGuinness; spoilt votes deemed ‘big rebuke to political establishment’ by Maria Steen
scraped_content.authors: Irish Independent Newsdesk, Denise Calnan, Alan Caulfield, Cónal Thomas, Eva Marie Gibney, Darragh Nolan, Fionnán Sheahan, Seoirse Mulgrew

top_articles.title: Taoiseach suggests referendum on changing 'restrictive' process for getting on presidential ballot
top_articles.summary: One in eight votes were spoiled.

raw_entry.title: Taoiseach suggests referendum on changing 'restrictive' process for getting on presidential ballot

title_detail.value: Taoiseach suggests referendum on changing 'restrictive' process for getting on presidential ballot

raw_entry.summary: One in eight votes were spoiled.

summary_detail.value: One in eight votes were spoiled.

scraped_content.content:
TAOISEACH MICHEÁL MARTIN has said the Oireachtas may have to look at changing the process by which a person gets on the ballot in presidential elections, which he described as “restrictive”.

Martin was speaking to reporters yesterday evening in the wake of independent Catherine Connolly’s resounding victory in the presidential election, in which she won 63% of the vote.

While Connolly won by a historic margin, another record was broken yesterday, more people than ever spoiled their votes (one in eight).

Martin said: “It’s a worry, because I think, first of all, people are entitled to vote, people are entitled not to vote, and I suppose people are entitled in our system to spoil their votes.”

Advertisement

He said that this would need to be interpreted.

“I think there’s probably an issue with the restrictive nature of how one gets on the ballot, and that’s something that, collectively, the Oireachtas can look at,” he said.

There was a concerted campaign by people who supported the socially conservative would-be candidate Maria Steen, who did not make it onto the ballot, to encourage people to spoil their votes in protest at the nomination process.

“A lot of parties didn’t nominate candidates this time, so hence, by definition, you were going to have fewer candidates,” Martin said.

Changing the nomination process – whereby presidential hopefuls need 20 Oireachtas members or four local councils to back them – would require a referendum.

“Ultimately, that’s the only way you could do it,” Martin said, adding that it would require “some work between the political parties in the intervening period”.
scraped_content.title: Taoiseach suggests referendum on changing 'restrictive' process for getting on presidential ballot
scraped_content.authors: David Macredmond, Send Tip Or Correction, Christina Finn

Martin was speaking to reporters yesterday evening in the wake of independent Catherine Connolly’s resounding victory in the presidential election, in which she won 63% of the vote.

While Connolly won by a historic margin, another record was broken yesterday, more people than ever spoiled their votes (one in eight).

Martin said: “It’s a worry, because I think, first of all, people are entitled to vote, people are entitled not to vote, and I suppose people are entitled in our system to spoil their votes.”

He said that this would need to be interpreted.

“I think there’s probably an issue with the restrictive nature of how one gets on the ballot, and that’s something that, collectively, the Oireachtas can look at,” he said.

There was a concerted campaign by people who supported the socially conservative would-be candidate Maria Steen, who did not make it onto the ballot, to encourage people to spoil their votes in protest at the nomination process.

“A lot of parties didn’t nominate candidates this time, so hence, by definition, you were going to have fewer candidates,” Martin said.

Changing the nomination process – whereby presidential hopefuls need 20 Oireachtas members or four local councils to back them – would require a referendum.

“Ultimately, that’s the only way you could do it,” Martin said, adding that it would require “some work between the political parties in the intervening period”.

top_articles.title: Catherine Connolly, the underdog Independent TD who began her campaign before all the others
top_articles.summary: While the result was clear from very early on, that didn’t stop heightened emotions as the President-elect took to the podium at St Patrick’s Hall

raw_entry.title: Catherine Connolly, the underdog Independent TD who began her campaign before all the others

title_detail.value: Catherine Connolly, the underdog Independent TD who began her campaign before all the others

raw_entry.summary: While the result was clear from very early on, that didn’t stop heightened emotions as the President-elect took to the podium at St Patrick’s Hall

summary_detail.value: While the result was clear from very early on, that didn’t stop heightened emotions as the President-elect took to the podium at St Patrick’s Hall

raw_entry.author: news@irishmirror.ie (Ciara O'Loughlin)
raw_entry.media_keywords: Catherine Connolly, Irish presidential election, In the News, Politics, Politics

scraped_content.content:
Catherine Connolly, the underdog Independent TD who began her campaign before all the others

While the result was clear from very early on, that didn’t stop heightened emotions as the President-elect took to the podium at St Patrick’s Hall

View 2 Images Irish president-elect Catherine Connolly (C) is applauded by the other candidates at the official declaration at Dublin Castle (Image: Charles McQuillan/Getty Images)

She was the underdog Independent TD who began her campaign before all the others and won with a resounding 63.4 per cent of the vote.

‌



Cheers erupted and tears flowed as Catherine Connolly was announced as the 10th President of Ireland at Dublin Castle on Saturday night. While the result was clear from very early on, that didn’t stop heightened emotions as the President-elect took to the podium at St Patrick’s Hall.

‌



Ms Connolly has been praised for her ability in not giving too much away, but both joy and relief were visible on her face. Young kids donned Connolly-branded T-shirts as the Georgian room was filled with green and orange.

‌



The main honchos of her backing puddled together in the packed hall, including Sinn Féin’s Mary Lou McDonald, Social Democrats Holly Cairns and Labour’s Ivana Bacik.

Before being declared as the President, it was significant to watch Ms Connolly hugging all the female leaders that backed her, while her only opponent in the election was also a woman.

View 2 Images Irish president-elect Catherine Connolly addresses the audience at the official declaration at Dublin Castle (Image: Charles McQuillan/Getty Images)

‌



But unlike the Taoiseach, we are not strangers to a female President in this country, with Ms Connolly being the third after Mary Robinson and Mary McAleese.

Fine Gael's Heather Humphreys humbly stood on stage beside Taoiseach Micheál Martin and Tánaiste Simon Harris, but she couldn’t hide the disappointment on her face.

The President-Elect was joined at the podium by her adoring family, husband Brian McEnery and her adult sons. While Ms Connolly winning by a landslide was significant, the massive number of spoiled votes was really the story of the day.

‌



Even during her declaration the room was reminded about the 12.9 per cent of non-voters who spoiled their ballot. As invalid votes were announced by the returning officer, one man in the room screamed and cheered.

This was met by a disapproving look on the Tánaiste’s face, as everyone turned to look at who was making the noise. Despite her team knowing she had it in the bag for the week leading up to D-day, there were tears in the crowd when she was declared the President.

Article continues below

From a huge number of volunteers to her campaign manager, Beibhinn O'Connor, they were congratulated by all for their tireless work since July. With keepie uppies to unnamed cats and rollerblading escapades, her team managed to portray a persona outside politics. But it was her debating skills and ability to hold herself when asked tough questions that analysts say won her the vote.

And she finished off her campaign in Dublin Castle as she started- with a speech As Gaeilge reminding the country she will be a President for All, even to those who spoiled her votes.

Subscribe to our newsletter for the latest news from the Irish Mirror direct to your inbox: Sign up here.
scraped_content.title: Catherine Connolly, the underdog Independent TD who began her campaign before all the others

top_articles.title: Some FF TDs discussing Martin's leadership, says Lahart
top_articles.summary: Members of the Fianna Fáil parliamentary party are actively talking about Taoiseach Micheál Martin's leadership, a senior TD has said.

raw_entry.title: Some FF TDs discussing Martin's leadership, says Lahart

title_detail.value: Some FF TDs discussing Martin's leadership, says Lahart

raw_entry.summary: Members of the Fianna Fáil parliamentary party are actively talking about Taoiseach Micheál Martin's leadership, a senior TD has said.

summary_detail.value: Members of the Fianna Fáil parliamentary party are actively talking about Taoiseach Micheál Martin's leadership, a senior TD has said.

scraped_content.content:
Members of the Fianna Fáil parliamentary party are actively talking about Taoiseach Micheál Martin's leadership, a senior TD has said.

In a potentially significant intervention, John Lahart told RTÉ News that he agreed with his colleague John McGuinness that there must be a discussion about the leadership.

Mr McGuinness said that the party needs a new leader in the not too distant future.

"It is a conversation that the party needs to have. The events of the last few weeks, the result yesterday, and the outcome of the result have brought that conversation forward," Mr Lahart said.

John Lahart said the centre has not held politically

He said there was a huge amount of respect for Mr Martin and what he has achieved as leader over 14 years, but the Presidential election result reflected an error of judgement that will have consequences.

Mr Lahart said the centre has not held politically and a left-right divide has been created in Irish politics for the first time.

"I don't think Fianna Fáil can just sit back and observe that," he said.

Mr McGuinness, who is a TD for Carlow-Kilkenny, said the party needs a new leader "in the not too distant future".

Speaking on RTÉ's This Week, he said the party made "serious errors" in the presidential election campaign, which ultimately saw its candidate Jim Gavin dropping out of contention.

Mr Gavin was the candidate put forward by Mr Martin and deputy leader Jack Chambers after expressions of interest from other hopefuls including MEP Billy Kelleher and former taoiseach Bertie Ahern.

Mr McGuinness said party members are "extremely disappointed by the lack of selection process" in the election.

He said: "They were not consulted, councillors were not consulted, TDs were not consulted, the national executive was not consulted - so as a result of that inaction, we have arrived a situation where the campaign itself turned into a shambles."

'Shocking embarrassment for members of the party'

Mr McGuinness said the party now stood at 17% in opinion polls, which is where it stood in 2011.

"We do have to look at the structures within the party, but we also have to question the leadership team, which is made up of the Taoiseach, some unelected advisers and Fianna Fail headquarters."

Asked if the candidate selection was mostly Mr Martin's responsibility, Mr McGuinness said it was and added: "The selection of Jim Gavin came at a time when the leadership team decided that Billy Kelleher should not be the candidate, so they announced Jim Gavin's candidacy, and that in turn caused a vote - there was a contrived majority."

John McGuinness said the party made 'serious errors' in the presidential election

He said the whole election exposed "weaknesses" in Fianna Fáil and "was just a shocking embarrassment for members of the party".

Mr McGuinness said the presidential election has underlined the need for Fianna Fáil to "reinvent itself for the future".

Asked whether that meant a new leader, he said: "In due course, yes."

Pressed on when that should happen, Mr McGuinness replied: "Firstly we have to examine what happened in this election - but I think it's quite clear what happened - and I think it's quite clear what needs to be done some time in the not too distant future."

It has been suggested that Mr Martin may continue as leader and Taoiseach until the end of Ireland's presidency of the EU Council in December 2026.

However, Mr McGuinness said: "Quite frankly, I don't think the party can wait until then. I think the party must reflect immediately on what happened and take the appropriate steps."

He said there should be an "open discussion within the next 10 days".

Mr McGuinness contended it was a majority viewpoint within the party that there should be a "root-and-branch change".
scraped_content.title: Some FF TDs discussing Martin's leadership, says Lahart

top_articles.content:
Members of the Fianna Fáil parliamentary party are actively talking about Taoiseach Micheál Martin's leadership, a senior TD has said.

In a potentially significant intervention, John Lahart told RTÉ News that he agreed with his colleague John McGuinness that there must be a discussion about the leadership.

Mr McGuinness said that the party needs a new leader in the not too distant future.

"It is a conversation that the party needs to have. The events of the last few weeks, the result yesterday, and the outcome of the result have brought that conversation forward," Mr Lahart said.

John Lahart said the centre has not held politically

He said there was a huge amount of respect for Mr Martin and what he has achieved as leader over 14 years, but the Presidential election result reflected an error of judgement that will have consequences.

Mr Lahart said the centre has not held politically and a left-right divide has been created in Irish politics for the first time.

"I don't think Fianna Fáil can just sit back and observe that," he said.

Mr McGuinness, who is a TD for Carlow-Kilkenny, said the party needs a new leader "in the not too distant future".

Speaking on RTÉ's This Week, he said the party made "serious errors" in the presidential election campaign, which ultimately saw its candidate Jim Gavin dropping out of contention.

Mr Gavin was the candidate put forward by Mr Martin and deputy leader Jack Chambers after expressions of interest from other hopefuls including MEP Billy Kelleher and former taoiseach Bertie Ahern.

Mr McGuinness said party members are "extremely disappointed by the lack of selection process" in the election.

He said: "They were not consulted, councillors were not consulted, TDs were not consulted, the national executive was not consulted - so as a result of that inaction, we have arrived a situation where the campaign itself turned into a shambles."

'Shocking embarrassment for members of the party'

Mr McGuinness said the party now stood at 17% in opinion polls, which is where it stood in 2011.

"We do have to look at the structures within the party, but we also have to question the leadership team, which is made up of the Taoiseach, some unelected advisers and Fianna Fail headquarters."

Asked if the candidate selection was mostly Mr Martin's responsibility, Mr McGuinness said it was and added: "The selection of Jim Gavin came at a time when the leadership team decided that Billy Kelleher should not be the candidate, so they announced Jim Gavin's candidacy, and that in turn caused a vote - there was a contrived majority."

John McGuinness said the party made 'serious errors' in the presidential election

He said the whole election exposed "weaknesses" in Fianna Fáil and "was just a shocking embarrassment for members of the party".

Mr McGuinness said the presidential election has underlined the need for Fianna Fáil to "reinvent itself for the future".

Asked whether that meant a new leader, he said: "In due course, yes."

Pressed on when that should happen, Mr McGuinness replied: "Firstly we have to examine what happened in this election - but I think it's quite clear what happened - and I think it's quite clear what needs to be done some time in the not too distant future."

It has been suggested that Mr Martin may continue as leader and Taoiseach until the end of Ireland's presidency of the EU Council in December 2026.

However, Mr McGuinness said: "Quite frankly, I don't think the party can wait until then. I think the party must reflect immediately on what happened and take the appropriate steps."

He said there should be an "open discussion within the next 10 days".

Mr McGuinness contended it was a majority viewpoint within the party that there should be a "root-and-branch change".
top_articles.ai_summary: Recent developments in the Irish government have seen Minister for Finance Paschal Donohoe announce a new budget aimed at addressing the rising cost of living, with significant allocations for housing and healthcare. Opposition TDs have criticized the budget for not doing enough to support low-income families, with Sinn Féin's Pearse Doherty calling for more immediate relief measures. The budget's implications are expected to resonate across constituencies, particularly in urban areas facing housing crises. Polling data indicates a shift in public sentiment, with growing support for alternative parties as citizens express dissatisfaction with the current government's handling of economic issues.

top_articles.title: Opposition hoping Connolly win paves way for Govt change
top_articles.summary: It is clear though that the Government parties exited the count result in Dublin Castle last night weakened, as an emboldened left-wing alliance believe their time in power is edging ever closer, writes Mícheál Lehane.

raw_entry.title: Opposition hoping Connolly win paves way for Govt change

title_detail.value: Opposition hoping Connolly win paves way for Govt change

raw_entry.summary: It is clear though that the Government parties exited the count result in Dublin Castle last night weakened, as an emboldened left-wing alliance believe their time in power is edging ever closer, writes Mícheál Lehane.

summary_detail.value: It is clear though that the Government parties exited the count result in Dublin Castle last night weakened, as an emboldened left-wing alliance believe their time in power is edging ever closer, writes Mícheál Lehane.

scraped_content.content:
It was the poet Patrick Kavanagh who spoke about learning the art of not caring what others think and having the courage to stick to your beliefs.

It is a quality that Catherine Connolly exuded from the first day of this campaign.

That idea of quietly but steadfastly holding firm to contentious views is rare.

To do so with poise is even more unusual, but it is something she perfected.

However, her opponents will contend that there was an evasiveness to many of her answers.

But the result proves that her election pitch resonated and chimed with the prevailing sentiment of the majority of people who came out to vote on Friday.

Catherine Connolly flanked by supporters in Dublin Castle last night

It was a movement that was populated by one of the most precious political commodities, droves of young people.

Others will now try to replicate both this approach and her campaign's successful and slick social media work.

Such a move should come with a warning as that which looks simple in execution is usually the result of well-thought-out preparation.

It all suggests that her approach to the presidency will be a thoughtful and considered one.

Read more: President congratulates president-elect Connolly on 'momentous day for her'

Indeed, she has spoken about the importance of listening before making public utterances.

The experienced barrister has already pointed to the constitutional parameters of the role but added that she would be an independent president with an independent mind.

She has voiced empathy with those who did not vote for her by expressing an awareness of their concerns.

It is likely to be a theme that she will have to return to again, especially given the unprecedented number of people who registered their discontent with the political system by spoiling their vote.

Micheál Martin is facing calls to step down in January 2027

Catherine Connolly has pledged to be a tireless advocate for the welfare of the people, something that will be evident in her public statements and no doubt in her regular discussions with the Taoiseach.

"I find them very thought provoking and pleasant meetings," Micheál Martin said last night when outlining how these chats typically unfold.

The Galway West TD's elevation to the office of president puts her above the political fray but she has emphasised the importance of being a voice for peace, neutrality and climate action.

The parties that helped propel her campaign ardently believe her success helps pave the way for a change of Government.

While there is no doubting the growing sense of common purpose among left-wing parties, the next general election could be four years away.

The Galway West by-election to replace Catherine Connolly in the Dáil, which is expected to take place in May, could offer a glimpse of the strength of this alliance, over six months after the presidential election.

In the short term, the most intense fallout from this election will be felt by the Fianna Fáil leader.

Read more: Presidential Election coverage

Micheál Martin's decision to effusively embrace Jim Gavin's candidacy may well have shortened his time as Taoiseach.

For the first time, some within his party have stated publicly that he should step down in January 2027.

Under the current arrangements, Fianna Fáil is due to hold the position of Taoiseach until November of that year.

It was a far from ideal election from Fine Gael, but party leader Simon Harris can point to a 30% vote for a candidate who was after all a replacement for its first choice, Mairead McGuinness.

It is clear though that the Government parties exited the count result in Dublin Castle last night weakened, as an emboldened left-wing alliance believe their time in power is edging ever closer.

top_articles.ai_summary: Recent developments in the Irish government have seen TDs from various parties voicing their concerns over proposed budget cuts that could impact social services. Minister for Finance has defended the government's stance, stating that fiscal responsibility is crucial for economic stability. The opposition has criticized these measures, arguing they disproportionately affect vulnerable communities. Polling data indicates a shift in public sentiment, with rising support for alternative parties as citizens express dissatisfaction with current policies.

top_articles.title: From deepfakes to viral clips – how the Irish presidential race unfolded online
top_articles.summary: Social media is a key battleground in every modern election, but with fewer candidates and an entire country to canvass, it is especially important in a presidential race.

top_articles.ai_summary: Recent developments in Irish politics have seen TDs from various parties respond to the government's proposed budget cuts, with significant pushback from opposition leaders. The Minister for Finance has defended the measures, citing economic constraints, while critics argue that these cuts will disproportionately affect vulnerable communities. Polling data indicates a shift in public opinion, with growing support for alternative policies aimed at social equity, raising questions about the government's long-term strategy and its implications for upcoming elections.

top_articles.title: Man charged in connection with alleged assaults on two people canvassing with Mary Lou McDonald
top_articles.summary: The suspect is expected to appear in court in Dublin tomorrow morning.

raw_entry.title: Man charged in connection with alleged assaults on two people canvassing with Mary Lou McDonald

title_detail.value: Man charged in connection with alleged assaults on two people canvassing with Mary Lou McDonald

raw_entry.summary: The suspect is expected to appear in court in Dublin tomorrow morning.

summary_detail.value: The suspect is expected to appear in court in Dublin tomorrow morning.

scraped_content.content:
A MAN ARRESTED in connection with an alleged assault on two females while Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald was canvassing in Dublin has been charged.

The alleged assault took place on North Strand Road, Dublin 1 on Friday while McDonald was out encouraging people to vote for Catherine Connolly in the presidential election.

Advertisement

The suspect is expected to appear in court in Dublin tomorrow morning.

A video circulated online showing canvassers standing between McDonald and a man who was verbally abusing her and other members of the group. He also threatened to hit McDonald and others.

A woman was subsequently brought to hospital for medical examination.
scraped_content.title: Man charged in connection with alleged assaults on two people canvassing with Mary Lou McDonald

top_articles.ai_summary: Recent developments in the Irish government have seen TDs from various parties debating the implications of new housing policies aimed at addressing the ongoing crisis. Minister for Housing, Darragh O'Brien, has faced criticism from opposition leaders regarding the effectiveness of these measures, with calls for more immediate action to support struggling citizens. Additionally, recent polling data indicates a shift in public opinion, with rising support for Sinn Féin as they capitalize on government dissatisfaction, potentially reshaping the political landscape ahead of the next election.
